A question for you I couldn't possibly answer myself with all the Google access. I could muster...  I want to use a TEC or multiple TECs for cooling a water system, I'm happy to power these and deal with cooling etc I'mnot that fussed about theor efficiency, however, these TEGs are always prefaced with being massively inefficient, so... if I run the TECs to do their cooling job, would it make sense for me to use TEGs as heat sinks, loop the power generated back into the system and recover 5% whilst efficiently cooling the TECs using the seekbeck effect? IE it will absorb the heat "inefficiently" doing exactly what I need it to whilst also recycling some of the heat generated, I'm guessing it would make more sense to have a heat sink to build up a stable heat in something then have the TEGs feeding off the heat of that? Rather than trying to stick them directly to each other like hot output of TEC to hot input of TEG? I'm not looking to make a perpetual motion machine or anything, but it seems like I'm killing about 4 birds with one stone by doing this? I'm not sure I fully understand them though, so it would be good to have other input

A Stirling Engine is about 40% efficient in converting thermal energy into kinetic energy and a brushless motor is about 80% efficient so with those figures I would argue that producing electricity by means of a Stirling Engine and the brushless motor is the better option when considering conservation. My country is facing some difficulty with supplying power, they're "load shedding" which means each province is effected on a rotational basis. I'm considering utilizing the thermal mass of hot water storef in a spare geyser to generate enough electricity to power the lights at the very least.

The N and P type semiconductors are made of the same materials, I think, as light emitting diodes. They're (generally?) made of silicon and germanium but also injected with other materials, such as "phosphorus (P), arsenic (As), or antimony (Sb)" (Toshiba, 2022) for N type semiconductors and "boron (B) or indium (In)" (Toshiba, 2022) for P type semiconductors. It's unlikely that you'd be able to construct them yourself.  https://toshiba.semicon-storage.com/us/semiconductor/knowledge/e-learning/discrete/chap1/chap1-3.html https://toshiba.semicon-storage.com/us/semiconductor/knowledge/e-learning/discrete/chap1/chap1-4.html

In case of wiring you would need to provide it with a higher Voltage. In case of physically daisy changing them I don't see the use because the second element in the row would need to pump even more heat than the first one even pulled from the cold side. The temperature increase on the hot side is much greater than the temperature decrease on the cold side. For greater cooling capabilities you would space the pertier elements over a large surface.
